As an outcome of what is believed to have been protests made
by administrative officers at the
Hopkins against certain features
of the recent sophomore banquet in April, Student Council
last week adopted definite measures in regard to future banquets held by any J. H. U. class.
These regulations are to go into
effect at once. However, they
will be given their first real test
in April, 1933, during the froshsoph banquet season.

Constitutional By-Law Provides For Return Of

Milton Smith, who is president of
the Musical Club, was last week
named to head the Student Activities Council for the academic year
1932-33. Charles Squire, who represents the Debating Society on the
activity-governing group at Hopkins, was chosen secretary.
May Make Motion Today

Representatives to the three undergraduate publications on the
campus yesterday indicated that at
the Council's meeting today a move
will be begun to have removed the
clause in the organization's new constitution which reads: "Before any
profit sharing be participated in, all
mo~er; received, from the Student
Acttv1ties fee shall be returned to
the Student Activities Council to
use as it sees fit." It is said that
this clause was placed in the constitution, when it was newly drawn
up last year, upon pressure of the
administration and the faculty committee of student affairs. Should
the proposed motion be passed at
noon today by the Student Activities
Council at its meeting the authorities of the Hopkins concerned with
this will be formerlly petitioned to
reconsider the matter, it was indicated by representatives of the
campus activities.

clause is primarily is apparently a
mystery to heads of the three undergraduate publications which are to
be hit hard by the provision made in
it. Arguments are made that the

TUESDAY, MAY 17, 1932

To William Triplett
CONGRATULATIONS are due
William Triplett upon not only his
election to the presidency of Student
Council but his refusal to play politics.
Doug. Stone, the defeated candidate,
is to be commended for his declension
to do likewise.
It is our belief that Triplett will
efficiently, intelligently, and wisely
conduct his highly important office.
He is a man of high character, likeable personality, good judgment, and
ability. Having had three year's experience on the Council, he will, doubtless, prove to be a worthy president of
Student Council.
---0----

A Commendable Move

graduate weekly of the U-p.iversity of
Maryland if the statements of its acting editor, W. C. H. Needham, can be
regarded as official, appears to be quite
wrought up about the editorial policy
of this paper. This interesting fact
cannot be withheld any. longer.
Our views on especially R. 0. T. C.
have been marked "narrow" by our
contemporary at College Park. In
answer to strenuous objections from
The Diwmondback editor on our demand for the abolition of R. 0. T. C. at
Hopkins it was pointed out by us that
the conditions under which that
organization exists at U. of M. and
Hopkins are totally different.
Commenting upon an artcile by
Donald Proctor, associate editor of
this paper, Mr. Needham wrote: "Your
Mr. Proctor, in his recent atricle in
THE NEWS-LETTER, admitted himself
to be a 'rank pacifist'; in all fairness,
how about giving your military department a hand in the argument?
If you, as a proponent of policies so
completely unamerican, fail to give
your collegiate 'public' both sides of
the question, you ought to be
;pilloried."
That sentiment is identical with
that of a few Hopkins men. But, the
men connected with the military
science department here have been invited to contribute articles to T HE
NEWS-LETTER. Our offer has not been
accepted. The columns of this paper
are open to all.
In a communication, last week, Mr .
Needham, in ridiculing our editorial
"Standing Firm," remarked: "Editorially, you claim that you do not
represent campus opinion-that you're
determined to mold the campus
opinion; to set forth what we see best
for the un der graduate department of
the University. Very prettily said ...
Can you set yourself up, as an a ma teur Mussolini, and throw h uge disfiguring splotches of black ink across
the name of one of the most outstanding universities in the United States?
'That's doing a lot of molding for a
sophomore. Mr. Levin!"
' Again Mr. Needham, doubtless voicing t he opinion of his staff, holds the
view similar to that of some Hopkin s
men who are dissatisfied because this
paper h as finally dared to say what it
believes.
Just as T he Diamondback has
fought successfully for the eradication of "dirty" fraternity politics from
the Maryland campus, the only major
plank in the paper's editorial platform, THE NEWS-LETTER is attacking
and asking for reforms for a number
of unfortunate situations on t he
campus at Homewood. What is wrong
in that?
Why there should be any objections
on the part of The Diarrwndback or of
any Hopkins man to our editorial
policy we do not know. We are stating what we believe to be right, and
we mean what we say.
The Diarrwnbdack editor cannot refrain from commenting upon our editorials.·
Because of his muchappreciated interest in them, we have
found it impossible to refrain from
making public hw views on these
editorials.

TWO great lacrosse teams will
clash on Saturday at the Baltimore
Stadium in one of the most important
Indian stick battles since 1928. Two
equally brilliant attacks of the two
State twelves will be pitted against
each other.
The strength of both the Jays and
the Terps is well known by all concerned.
The game on Saturday
promises, as a consequence, to be
really a brilliant affair. There is no
room for both Hopkins and Maryland
on the top rung of the national lacrosse ladder--one of the two twelves
must, after Saturday, take a place on
the next rung down. But which team
will do so, whe hesitate to prophecy.
We recognize the fact Hopkin's attack carries plenty of "voltage" and
is virtually a "powerhouse." Its brilliancy and speed have been instrumental in bowling over seven consecutive twelves this season. Turnbull,
Stone, Don Kelly, Darrell, Guild and
Beehler h a ve performed excellently.
The Jays met the challenges of two
Olympic contenders, Army and Mt.
Washington, in marvelous style.
But we recognize, likewise, that
Maryland has a fast-stepping, dangerous stick-wielding machine.
All that we can say is that in this
evenly-matched lacrosse tilt on Saturday we wish the Jays the best of luck.

Flashing some real lacrosse that
caused Lhe "regulars" no little concern, the Jay reserve twelve swamped Washington College in a onesided setto at Homewood last
Saturday.
Though Coach Van Orman saw
fit to start his first string combination, he soon removed them from
the fray and inserted the second
attack, who were to carry the
burden of the play for the rest of
the afternoon. This move followed
the netting of two goals in the opening minutes of the game.
Reinhold Stats For Lossers
The Shoreman had their hands
full in making the afternoon interesting for the reserves, who
scored almost at will, but for the
work of Reinhold, Maroon and
Black goalie. The diminutive goal·
tender was in the way of enough
shots to win an ordinary game.
Shot after shot was batted away or
caught in the net of the agile keeper
much to the consternation of the
few Hopkins rooters that braved
the threatening weather and ·the
Preakness temptation to witness the
contest.

Weather-Proof Address
President J. R. Angell, of Yale,
was the second speaker. He referred to himself as being from
New England and coming with a
weather-proof adress. He compared the holding of an outdoor
address in Maryland, on this occasion, to a man who enters upon
his second marriage relying on
hope rather than experience.
Dr. Angell explained that the

furniture now in the Homewood
House has Geen loaned Gy the
Mabel Grady Garvan Institute of
Yale, which is circulating its
treasures throughout the country.
The other speakers were Dr.
R. T. H. Halsey, professor of colonial art at St. Johns College .
and the Rev. John F. Fenlo n, rector of St. Mary's Seminary, who
re'p resented Archbishop Curley.
Dr: Halsey commented at length
on the history of the home and
its builder and the furnishing novv
therein. Father Fenelon spoke
about the Carroll championship
of religious liberty.

TUESDAY, MAY 17, 1932

To William Triplett
CONGRATULATIONS are due
William Triplett upon not only his
election to the presidency of Student
Council but his refusal to play politics.
Doug. Stone, the defeated candidate,
is to be commended for his declension
to do likewise.
It is our belief that Triplett will
efficiently, intelligently, and wisely
conduct his highly important office.

graduate weekly of the U-p.iversity of
Maryland if the statements of its acting editor, W. C. H. Needham, can be
regarded as official, appears to be quite
wrought up about the editorial policy
of this paper. This interesting fact
cannot be withheld any. longer.
Our views on especially R. 0. T. C.
have been marked "narrow" by our
contemporary at College Park. In
answer to strenuous objections from
The Diwmondback editor on our demand for the abolition of R. 0. T. C. at
Hopkins it was pointed out by us that
the conditions under which that
organization exists at U. of M. and
Hopkins are totally different.
Commenting upon an artcile by
Donald Proctor, associate editor of
this paper, Mr. Needham wrote: "Your
Mr. Proctor, in his recent atricle in
THE NEWS-LETTER, admitted himself
to be a 'rank pacifist'; in all fairness,
how about giving your military department a hand in the argument?
If you, as a proponent of policies so
completely unamerican, fail to give
your collegiate 'public' both sides of
the question, you ought to be
;pilloried."
That sentiment is identical with
that of a few Hopkins men. But, the
men connected with the military
science department here have been invited to contribute articles to T HE
NEWS-LETTER. Our offer has not been
accepted. The columns of this paper
are open to all.
In a communication, last week, Mr .
Needham, in ridiculing our editorial
"Standing Firm," remarked: "Editorially, you claim that you do not
represent campus opinion-that you're
determined to mold the campus
opinion; to set forth what we see best
for the un der graduate department of
the University. Very prettily said ...
Can you set yourself up, as an a ma teur Mussolini, and throw h uge disfiguring splotches of black ink across
the name of one of the most outstanding universities in the United States?
'That's doing a lot of molding for a
sophomore. Mr. Levin!"
' Again Mr. Needham, doubtless voicing t he opinion of his staff, holds the
view similar to that of some Hopkin s
men who are dissatisfied because this
paper h as finally dared to say what it
believes.
Just as T he Diamondback has
fought successfully for the eradication of "dirty" fraternity politics from
the Maryland campus, the only major
plank in the paper's editorial platform, THE NEWS-LETTER is attacking
and asking for reforms for a number
of unfortunate situations on t he
campus at Homewood. What is wrong
in that?
Why there should be any objections
on the part of The Diarrwndback or of
any Hopkins man to our editorial
policy we do not know. We are stating what we believe to be right, and
we mean what we say.

found it impossible to refrain from
making public hw views on these

TWO great lacrosse teams will
clash on Saturday at the Baltimore
Stadium in one of the most important
Indian stick battles since 1928. Two
equally brilliant attacks of the two
State twelves will be pitted against
each other.
The strength of both the Jays and
the Terps is well known by all concerned.
The game on Saturday
promises, as a consequence, to be
really a brilliant affair. There is no
room for both Hopkins and Maryland
on the top rung of the national lacrosse ladder--one of the two twelves
must, after Saturday, take a place on
the next rung down. But which team
will do so, whe hesitate to prophecy.
We recognize the fact Hopkin's attack carries plenty of "voltage" and
is virtually a "powerhouse." Its brilliancy and speed have been instrumental in bowling over seven consecutive twelves this season. Turnbull,
Stone, Don Kelly, Darrell, Guild and
Beehler h a ve performed excellently.
The Jays met the challenges of two
Olympic contenders, Army and Mt.
Washington, in marvelous style.
But we recognize, likewise, that
Maryland has a fast-stepping, dangerous stick-wielding machine.
All that we can say is that in this
evenly-matched lacrosse tilt on Saturday we wish the Jays the best of luck.
